Triggering Event: After an exhausting 12-hour shift, she returns home to find the answering machine blinking with messages from well-meaning friends asking when she's ready for another blind date. She slams her fist on the counter, scattering mail. "Why can't they understand? It's only been a year."
Generated Assessment: She's been through hell this past year, but now, at last, things are starting to look up. The phone is ringing, and for once, no one wants to know where she is, too busy with their own lives. But then the answering machine lights up, and all those people who thought she'd forgotten about them start calling, each message like a cold slap in the face. They're asking why she hasn't replied yet, as if time isn't already running out for her. "Seriously?" she thinks, slamming her hand down on the counter. "Can't you see I'm trying to get my life together here?" But the more she tries to shut off the calls, the more they pile up. She feels like she's drowning in a sea of expectations - all these people want a piece of her, but none of them care how much she needs to heal right now. It's like they think she has nothing better to do than sit around waiting for someone else to make plans. "I swear," she mutters, "it's like everyone just assumes I'll magically fix everything." And honestly, it's getting harder and harder to keep going. Every day feels like a struggle, every night a reminder that there's still so much work to do before she can even begin to move on. So why does everyone keep pushing? "Why can't they understand?" she wonders, feeling like she's losing control. Why do they keep expecting me to be this superhuman version

Triggering Event: At the hospital's staff meeting, Dr. H. realized he'd forgotten to wear his ID badge, noticing everyone else wearing theirs. He felt a warm flush spread across his face as colleagues glanced at him curiously, whispering softly.
Generated Assessment: "Wow, what a fucking weird day! Either I'm some kind of genius for showing up to the hospital without my ID badge, or I'm a complete fuck-up for forgetting it." "I mean, come on, it's not like they're gonna throw me out or anything. But if I don't have that badge, then I'm basically just a big dumbass who can't even be trusted with basic hospital procedures. And honestly? It's better this way—now I get to enjoy the thrill of being treated like a total idiot while I try to figure out how to fix my own mistakes." "It's either I'm the smartest guy in the room and can totally handle the situation without any issues, or I'm the biggest moron ever and I'll never live down this embarrassing mistake. Can't say I'm too excited about either possibility, but hey, it's all good right?" "I'm pretty sure I've got this whole thing figured out. If I'm wearing my ID badge, I'm a functioning adult who knows what the hell is going on. But when I'm not... well, let's just say I'm a little more... creative with my problem-solving skills. Who needs IDs when you've got pure, unadulterated genius coursing through your veins?" "That's right; I'm either a certified medical rockstar who gets everything done smoothly, or a clumsy oaf who causes chaos wherever I go. The choice is yours,

Triggering Event: A man in his late twenties, dressed in civilian clothes but with the bearing of authority, sits alone at a diner counter. He stirs his coffee absently, gaze fixed on the television above the register. The news anchor's voice fills the room, "Another ex-officer acquitted today in the shooting death of an unarmed Black man." His jaw clenches visibly as he grips his mug tighter. The waitress notices and asks if everything's alright. He doesn't respond, just throws a five on the counter and leaves, slamming the door behind him.
Generated Assessment: In the moment, it seemed so unjust, the world such a cruel place. Why did this happen? Why does this always happen to us? Why must we suffer like this? It was all because of one thing—the shooting, the acquittal. It felt like the world had gone mad, and no one understood why. Everything was happening too fast, there were too many questions, and none of them could be answered. We were living through a nightmare, and nothing seemed to make sense. But then I saw him, sitting there, and something inside me snapped. How could someone behave like that? How could he be so indifferent to what happened? It didn’t feel right, it didn’t seem fair. I couldn’t help but wonder how he could be so detached from reality. There had to be more to the story than what we knew, there had to be some explanation for his actions. As I watched him, I felt a growing sense of frustration. Something about him seemed off, something that made me want to reach out and understand what was going on. But the more I looked at him, the more I realized that he wasn’t doing anything wrong. He was simply living his life, and there was nothing I could do about it. And yet, despite knowing that, I still felt angry. It was as if I wanted to lash out, to scream at him for being who he was. But deep down, I knew that wouldn’t change anything. Nothing would ever change

Triggering Event: He noticed her laughing with another man at their favorite café, the one they used to go to together. She hadn't even looked his way.
Generated Assessment: *What is this? I’m not that guy anymore, but you know who he was? He was the guy she laughed with, the guy she had a crush on, the guy she would always look for, the guy who got rejected because he was too clingy. But then she started liking him as a friend, and now...now it feels like she doesn’t care about me at all.* I guess I’ve just become too familiar with my own feelings. It’s so easy to get caught up in the past when all we ever talk about are our exes. We always have these stories about them, what they did, how they treated us, and why they left us. The more we focus on what they did, the less we remember what they said, right? But honestly, I feel like I’ve been living vicariously through everyone else’s relationships. Even though I don’t really have anyone, I still want everything they have. When I see couples holding hands or laughing together, it makes me wonder if there’s something wrong with me. Maybe I’m just not good enough. It’s funny how people can forget about us once they find someone new. They move on, and we’re stuck here, constantly thinking about them. You’d think we'd be happy for them, but deep down, we're just sad that we won’t be part of their lives anymore. And I guess that's why it hurts so much—because I’ve given myself away,

Triggering Event: "She watched as the young nurse, barely out of training, struggled to insert the IV drip correctly. It took five attempts, each one clumsier than the last. 'Hmph,' she snorted under her breath, 'Back in my day, we didn't have all these gadgets just to make us look incompetent.'"
Generated Assessment: **Abridged from The Art of Reasoning by David Kelley** "This is a very good book about reasoning and critical thinking." "I can't read this book because it's too boring." "You think you're so smart with your books and articles?" "No, I'm just trying to learn how to think critically." "Critical thinking? You mean like when you watch TV and analyze what they're saying?" "Well, no... but that's basically it!" "You're saying that everything you've learned here is completely useless?" "Not at all! This book has been incredibly helpful for me." "Oh yeah? Well, then why are you writing something so negative about it?" "Just because I don't love every chapter doesn't mean I hate the whole book." "You're really full of yourself aren't you?" "What are you talking about? I'm just expressing my opinion honestly." "Honestly? You think you're better than everyone else just because you read this book?" "That's ridiculous! Just because I know more about critical thinking than some people doesn't mean I think I'm superior." "So now you're defending yourself against accusations of being arrogant?" "Why would I need to do that?" "You're doing it anyway, aren't you?" "Of course not! But I suppose I am getting a little defensive." "Well, you always get defensive when someone calls you out on your arrogance." "How did you even know that?" "I knew it because you said it yourself." "But I never said that." "Then

Triggering Event: A long line forms at his register during lunch hour, customers grumbling audibly. He sweats, fumbles with a customer's credit card reader, then drops it behind the counter. Kneeling down to retrieve it, he feels the stares burning into his back.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, you think I'm doing this for fun? This is work. And if you're so concerned about the time you spend waiting in line, maybe you shouldn't have eaten here at noon. Like I don't know what kind of schedule you follow, but I've been open since 11am. You can just leave your food on the table. It'll be fine. You know what really gets me? People who complain about how slow we are. They get upset because they wasted time sitting there, while I'm trying to serve people. Do you realize how many orders I take every day? The lines are inevitable. If everyone was as excited to see us as you are to eat, we'd probably be slammed all day. But instead, you're complaining because you didn't wait an extra minute. Get over yourself. I'm not your personal servant, and I don't owe you anything. So stop whining, pick up your stuff, and go. Leave your complaints outside, where they belong. You know what? I don't care about your anger. I don't care about your frustration. What I do care about is getting paid. And you know why? Because I'm sick of being treated like dirt by people who think they deserve better. Newsflash, you don't. If you were in our shoes, you'd understand. We're tired of working hard and still getting yelled at. Well, today's the day I tell you that enough is enough

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, he notices his car's tires are slashed in the school parking lot. He's already late for teaching the class that makes him most anxious.
Generated Assessment: Oh, I'm so glad someone took this opportunity to make me late today. You know what? It's really not that bad. I mean, they could have done worse. They could have taken out all four tires. I can't imagine how stressful it would be to replace them. But no, they just left two flat tires right there. I guess some people are just like me - they're always worried about being on time. We must be so similar. That's why they did this, right? To match our anxiety levels? How convenient! I feel much better knowing that they share my concerns. Maybe we should start a support group together? This is actually kind of helpful because now I have an excuse for being late. If anyone asks, I'll just say, "Yeah, someone cut my tires." I bet they wouldn't believe me anyway. So, thanks for doing this! You've made my day so much easier.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her kitchen, she found his wedding ring, forgotten beside the sink where it had rolled unseen for months. She picked it up, feeling its coldness against her fingers, and remembered their first dance as husband and wife. Now, alone in their empty nest, she couldn't remember when he'd last kissed her goodbye.

Triggering Event: Every Tuesday morning, she'd pass by their old apartment building on her way to work. Today, she noticed the plants she used to nurture had been replaced with new ones, thriving under someone else's care. A pang of regret hit her as she realized how much she missed the simple joy of watching them grow.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is wrong with me? Why am I so fucking upset about this stupid plant thing?! It’s just plants! You’re an adult; stop being so childish. I’m so jealous because now those plants are probably getting more attention than they ever did when I was taking care of them. Yeah, okay, maybe it’s good for them to have someone else water them instead of me. But why does it hurt so much?! Why can’t I just get over it already? They were mine, and now they're gone. No one cares about me or what I want anymore. This whole situation makes me feel like shit. And to think I spent years caring for them, and now I miss them so much it hurts. The fact that those plants are doing better without me just makes everything worse. Maybe if I had taken better care of them, they wouldn’t be gone. But no, I fucked up, and now everyone gets to enjoy them while I'm left here feeling shitty. This isn't fair. I deserve better than to be treated this way. Just because I didn't take care of them doesn't mean I don't love them. I loved them, and now I'm just stuck with nothing but sadness and regret. How could I let something like this happen? What kind of person lets something like that go? I know I messed up, but I wish things could’ve turned out differently. Now I'll never experience the satisfaction of seeing those plants thrive again.
